title: Unlocking Youth Potential: Understanding Nigeria’s YEDP (Youth Entrepreneurship Development Programme)
description: How the Youth Entrepreneurship Development Programme (YEDP) from the Central Bank of Nigeria supports young entrepreneurs with loans, training and business growth opportunities.
alt: Young Nigerian entrepreneurs under YEDP training and support

content.text: In Nigeria today, the youth make up a large portion of the population yet many face barriers to launching businesses: lack of capital, limited training, and uncertain paths. That’s where the Youth Entrepreneurship Development Programme (YEDP) steps in a major initiative by the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) designed to give young Nigerians the tools, funding and structure they need to build their own businesses and drive innovation.

The Youth Entrepreneurship Development Programme, commonly called YEDP, was launched by the CBN with the goal of harnessing the latent entrepreneurial skills of Nigeria’s youth, improving access to finance for young entrepreneurs and creating job opportunities.

When youth have viable businesses, the entire economy benefits. YEDP ties into broader goals of economic diversification, reducing youth unemployment, strengthening the non-oil sector and supporting small and medium enterprises (SMEs). For example, one bank participation noted that through YEDP it intends to empower youth entrepreneurs in Abia State with loans and training.

items: Young Nigerians between the ages of about 18-34 years (or similar age bracket depending on guidelines.
Serving members of the national youth service (NYSC) or those who completed NYSC not more than 5 years ago.
Young graduates with verifiable certificates, as well as artisans with technical or proficiency certificates.
Individuals or groups with viable business ideas in priority sectors (agriculture value chain, cottage industries, ICT, creative industries, etc.).

content.text: YEDP targets sectors with high job-creation potential. Qualifying activities include: agricultural value chains (e.g., fish farming, poultry, snail farming), cottage industries, creative industries, ICT, mining/solid minerals and other growth oriented activities. Trading alone is not eligible under the standard guidelines.

items: For a single applicant: up to approx. ₦3 million. For group projects (3-5 youth): up to approx. ₦10 million.
Maximum tenor for term loan: 36 months (varies by project); working capital facility: up to 12 months with possible 12-month rollover.
Interest: lending banks access fund at low rate (e.g., 2% from CBN) and may lend at a capped maximum rate (9% per annum all-inclusive).
Collateral typically includes NYSC discharge certificate (for graduates/NYSC members), tertiary certificate, technical certificate, third-party guarantors and movable asset registration.
Pre-qualification, business plan submission, online registration, training for beneficiaries.

content.text: Here’s a general step-by-step guide to applying (note: always check latest guidelines as banks/institutions may vary):

items: Visit participating bank’s portal or the official application site for YEDP.
Register your personal data and business idea; indicate whether you’re an individual or group applicant.
Provide required documents: valid ID, NYSC certificate or proof, tertiary certificate or technical certificate, business plan, proof of registration (if applicable).
Submit your proposal/business plan for evaluation by bank/CBN stakeholders.
Await pre-qualification, training invitation, final approval and disbursement of funds.
If approved, receive the loan and access supported training/mentorship as part of the programme.

content.text: Tips to Improve Your Approval Odds

items: Prepare a clear business plan showing viability, income prospects and job creation potential.
Choose sectors aligned with YEDP priority areas (agriculture, ICT, creative industries) rather than purely trading.
Ensure your documents are complete, correct and verifiable (NYSC, certificate, ID, etc).
Consider applying as a group (3-5 youth) if you have a strong shared business idea this may unlock higher funding limits.
Use the training/mentorship provided as part of the programme this shows commitment and may improve your proposal's strength.

content.text: Challenges & Things to Watch Out For

items: Even though YEDP offers favourable terms, the burden of proof and viability remains. Loans must be repaid.
Some applicants struggle with business planning or sustaining their ventures post-disbursement training matters.
Collaterals and guarantees may still be required; small youth-groups may face administrative hurdles.
Banks and institutions may have varying timelines and processes delays can occur.

content.text: Why YEDP is a Smart Move for You

If you’re a young Nigerian with a solid business idea, accessing funds is often the hardest part. YEDP offers one of the most realistic and structured pathways to get finance + training + support. Combine this with your drive, and you’re well-positioned to grow a business, create jobs and build real wealth while contributing to the wider economy.
